On Tue, 2003-06-17 at 18:55, J. B. Rainsberger wrote: 
> I disagree. Model objects representing values should be transparent, a la "Naked Objects". They should let the Model objects containing business logic "do with them what they may". There is a tendency in OOP to pretend there is behavior where there is no behavior. I think that is a mistake. Some objects in the system are just bags of data. I think public fields should do nicely there. Ward Cunningham has been experimenting with ignoring the prevaling paranoia against public data. I haven't seen him write anything on it yet, but it's good to test long-standing "rules".

I agree with that when it is applied to "data structures," the naked
objects you refer to, but not behavioral objects.  I don't think you
were applying it to the latter, I just wanted to be clear.

> One counterexample is an object with 20 fields. Perhaps 20 set methods is clearer, at least in a language like Java with positional parameters. (In Smalltalk it's exactly the same, so it doesn't matter.) Should an object have 20 fields? Perhaps not, but some do. It is not clear that breaking that 20-field objects into four 5-field objects is any better.

A twist on that... If that object needs to have 20 fields (which I don't
believe it does) you can group fields together into other objects such
that this object is a wrapper on 5 others, each with 4 fields.  The data
is still in one place, but it's creation is much less cumbersome and you
can create it in a sane state.

=jason
